title: How to Use Cranberries for Thanksgiving

steps.headline: Make cranberry sauce.
steps.description: Obvious maybe but there is nothing more delicious than fresh cranberry sauce rather than relying on the tinned variety.

steps.headline: Use cranberries as a stuffing.
steps.description: Cranberries provide a delicious tart, fresh and juicy flavor that permeates the food beautifully. You can substitute cranberries where you'd normally use raisins, currants or apricots - or combine them.

steps.headline: Add cranberries to mashed vegetables.
steps.description: A great way to enliven your mashed potato or mashed squash is the addition of soft, dried cranberries. Simply delicious!

steps.headline: Create a cranberry glaze.
steps.description: A glaze would be suitable for a baked ham or a ham steak. One good recipe is to blend a mixture of cinnamon, allspice, coriander and mustard with cranberry sauce.

steps.headline: Make turkey stir-fry with cranberries.
steps.description: Leftover turkey makes a great stir-fry and it is even better when jazzed up with fresh or dried cranberries. Add Asian-flavors or ginger for a perfect combination of flavors.

steps.headline: Be adventurous and modify the pumpkin pie.
steps.description: Add some dried cranberries to the pie for something deliciously different. If you like pecans, add these also.

steps.headline: Make baked squash and cranberries.
steps.description: Bake a squash (cut it in half) and add a filling consisting of mixed vegetables, fresh cranberries and pine nuts. This one will fly off the table.

steps.headline: Bake cranberry nut bread.
steps.description: Bake fruit bread with cranberries and pecan nuts instead of your usual raisins and other dried fruits makes a great Thanksgiving treat.

steps.headline: Use cranberries for dessert.
steps.description: Poach oranges, apricots, pears or other soft fruit and add fresh cranberries to the sugar syrup for a tangy contrast.

text: Make cranberry sauce. Obvious maybe but there is nothing more delicious than fresh cranberry sauce rather than relying on the tinned variety. Use cranberries as a stuffing. You can substitute cranberries where you'd normally use raisins, currants or apricots - or combine them. Add cranberries to mashed vegetables. Make turkey stir-fry with cranberries. Leftover turkey makes a great stir-fry and it is even better when jazzed up with fresh or dried cranberries. Add Asian-flavors or ginger for a perfect combination of flavors. Be adventurous and modify the pumpkin pie. Add some dried cranberries to the pie for something deliciously different. If you like pecans, add these also. Make baked squash and cranberries. Bake a squash (cut it in half) and add a filling consisting of mixed vegetables, fresh cranberries and pine nuts. This one will fly off the table. Bake cranberry nut bread. Bake fruit bread with cranberries and pecan nuts instead of your usual raisins and other dried fruits makes a great Thanksgiving treat. Use cranberries for dessert. Poach oranges, apricots, pears or other soft fruit and add fresh cranberries to the sugar syrup for a tangy contrast.
